intro: Spigelia pusilla, commonly known as the dwarf pinkroot, is a small herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae, which includes many toxic plants, and is characterized by its delicate, pinkish to reddish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded woodlands and has a short stem with opposite, ovate leaves. Its roots are tuberous and often have a reddish color, which contributes to its common name. Spigelia pusilla is a rare species, often found in specific microhabitats, and is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological role.
